In Atlanta this week, cardiologists are meeting to discuss new tests, diagnostic techniques and drugs.
But in the hallway, theyll be talking about economics.
Earlier this year, cardiologists saw the government cut payments for many tests they perform and they are not happy about it.
Seventy-three-year-old Hank Edelson(ph) couldnt be happier with his cardiologist, Dr. Joe Wilson.
Wilson is dedicated to his patients.
Let me take a listen to that heart of yours.
Wilson has a well-appointed office and a busy practice on the outskirts of Atlanta, Georgia.
I will be happy to do anything and everything I can to keep your heart working.
And all you have to is call me if there's any sense of that feeling coming back that you remember from '93.
Out of the examining room and in his office, Bible on his desk, a picture of Martin Luther King on the wall, Wilson admits he loves his job.
And when I go in there and I close the door, all the difficulties we have with health care go away, and it's just a matter about me and my patients.
Since January 1st, he's been dealing with a new difficulty: Medicare cut payments for tests that cardiologists do all the time, like echocardiograms and certain stress tests.
So, Wilson will be getting less for treating his elderly and disabled patients on Medicare.
The average community cardiology practice, over the next four years, will be looking at somewhere around a 30 percent reduction in reimbursement for Medicare patients.
Joe Wilson feels his practice is threatened.
The government officials who pushed for the change say theyve been paying cardiologists too much.
Wilson won't say what he makes for taking care of people's hearts but he says it's not far from the national average, and thats $400,000 a year.
I realize that that seems like a lot of money.
But the average cardiologist, like my young associate here, did not really start making any money in cardiology until he was 33, 34 years old.
He says cardiologists work long hours and are on call 24/7.
You're listening to NEWS & NOTES from NPR News.
And there was a real danger they weren't going to turn out and vote in the numbers he needed.
He started taking care of that.
But I think the middle-of-the-road voters who are actually accessible to Obama are going to like him better for fighting for something.
Of course, news today of the drone strike that killed al-Qaida terrorist Anwar al-Awlaki in Yemen.
Can President Obama make a compelling case of his record on anti-terrorism, on national security?
I think he can, but I don't thing that's ever going to be a campaign issue this year.
That's the thing that separates from Obama from the center right now.
